descriptions.content:
• སངས་རྒྱས་ “Buddha.” From buddha, “The Awakened One.” (Formed with the Tibetan སངས་ “awakened” and རྒྱས་ “expanded.”) Beyer comments that the Tibetan sangs-rgyas has been coined “on the basis of two different Sanskrit etymological glosses...: ‘He is like a man who has awakened (prabuddha) because his sleep of delusion has vanished,’ and...‘He is Buddha because his mind (buddhi) has opened up like a lotus that has expanded (vibuddha).’”[1]
  • བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་ “Bodhisattva” (bodhisattva). (Formed with བྱང་ “has purified faults,” ཆུབ་ “has assimilated [all] knowledge,” སེམས་ “mind,” and དཔའ་ “hero,” resulting in “hero of the mind who has purified his faults and has assimilated all knowledge.”)
  • ལས་ “Karma,” “Action” (karma).
  • སྟོང་པ་ཉིད་ “The void” (śūnyatā).
  • ལེགས་སྦྱར་ “Sanskrit.” From saṃskṛta, “well-composed (language).” (Formed with ལེགས་ excellent” and སྦྱར་ “put together” “composed.”)
  • འཁོར་བ་ “Transmigration” (saṃsāra). (Formed with འཁོར་ “to circle,” to mean “the round/cycle [of existence].”)
  • མྱ་ངན་ལས་འདས་པ་ “Nirvana.” From nirvāṇa, “blown out” “extinguished.” (The Tibetan is literally “passed beyond suffering.”)
  • ཉོན་མོངས་ “Negative emotions.” From kleśa, “torment.”
  • གྲུབ་ཐོབ་ཆེན་པོ་ “Mahāsiddha.” From mahasiddha, “masters with great accomplishments.” (Formed with གྲུབ་ “accomplishment,” ཐོབ་ “to obtain,” and ཆེན་པོ་ “big.”)

 

[1] See Stephan Beyer, The Classical Tibetan Language (Albany: State University of New York Press, 1992), 143-44.
